messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: The Hunger Games are a very dangerous TV game. In it, teenagers fight. 'Tributes' are the teenagers in the Games. The Capitol uses the Games to make the areas remember. They must remember that the Capitol punishes them. Every year, people pick one boy and one girl. This happens in every area. They are between 12 and 18 years old. They go to the Games and fight. Only one person stays alive. All people in the country must watch it on TV.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Factual Inaccuracy. The original text says “chosen from each district by lottery,” but the writer’s output says “people pick one boy and one girl” and drops the lottery mechanism. The original text also states the Capitol uses the Games to remind the districts they are being punished for rebelling, but the output only says “the Capitol punishes them,” omitting the reason of rebellion.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: The Hunger Games are a very dangerous event. They happen every year. People watch them on TV. The Capitol uses the Games to remind the districts. The districts rebelled before. The Games are their punishment. In each district, a lottery picks one boy and one girl. They are 12 to 18 years old. These teenagers are "tributes". "Tributes" means the teenagers in the Games. The tributes fight in the Games. Only one person stays alive. All people in the country must watch on TV.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: CEFR Vocabulary Failure. The text contains B1 or B2 level words not allowed at A2: remind (B1), districts (B1), punishment (B1), lottery (B1), means (B2). Suggestion: Replace these with A2-level words. For example, use tell again instead of remind, areas instead of districts, bad rule or pay for the action instead of punishment, draw names instead of lottery, and use is or says instead of means.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: The Hunger Games are a very dangerous event. They happen every year. The Capitol uses the Games to tell the areas again. The areas fought the Capitol before. The Games make them pay for that. In each area, they draw names. One boy and one girl go. They are 12 to 18 years old. People call them "tributes". Tributes are the teenagers in the Games. The tributes fight in the Games. Only one person stays alive. All people in the country must watch on TV.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT-Orig score of 0.6435 is below the required 0.75. - MeaningBERT score of 0.6435 is too low. - The phrase "tell the areas again" replaces "remind the districts that they are being punished for rebelling", losing the core nuance of punishment for rebellion.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: The Hunger Games are a very dangerous event. They happen every year. They are a fight. The Capitol uses the Games to punish the districts. The districts fought the Capitol before. The Games remind them of that old fight. In each district, they draw names. One boy and one girl go. They are 12 to 18 years old. People call them tributes. Tributes are the teenagers in the Games. The tributes fight in the Games. Only one person stays alive. All people in the country must watch on TV.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7339 is below the required 0.75, indicating significant loss of core message.
- The original phrase “chosen by lottery” is replaced with “draw names,” removing the explicit concept of a lottery selection.
- The original focus on “being punished for rebelling” is diluted to “remind them of that old fight,” losing the notion of punishment tied to rebellion.
- The nuanced description “battle in which only one person can survive” is oversimplified to “They are a fight.”
Suggestion: Reinsert “by lottery” to accurately reflect how tributes are chosen.
Suggestion: Restore the phrase “punished for rebelling” to preserve the original cause-and-effect meaning.
Suggestion: Rephrase to “battle in which only one person can survive” to maintain the intensity and specificity of the original text.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: The Hunger Games are a big event. They happen every year. The Games are a battle in which only one person can survive. The Capitol uses the Games to remind the districts. It reminds them they are punished for rebelling. In each district, they choose by lottery. They choose one boy and one girl. They are 12 to 18 years old. People call them “tributes”. Tributes are the teenagers in the Games. All people in the country must watch on television.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: CEFR Compliance. Classifier rated B1. The text uses B1 level vocabulary such as battle, survive, remind, district, lottery which are not in A2. The sentence “The Games are a battle in which only one person can survive.” uses the relative clause “in which,” a B1 grammar structure. Suggestion: Replace battle with fight, survive with win, lottery with draw, district with area. Remove the phrase “in which.” Use only A2 words. Keep sentences no more than five words long and use only and, but, so, because as connectors.
